story.text: This square represents every laundry worker in America. Each person inside the square represents about 50,000 Americans who do this job.

story.job: Laundry and dry-cleaning workers|Furniture finishers|Drywall and ceiling tile installers
story.text: Laundry workers are Standers→—people who are required to stand most of the time at work. Here are some other workers who are Standers.
On the left are ←Sitters—people who are almost always sitting at work.
Oh, and here’s you! We’ll keep track of you through this piece.
And in the middle is every other job in America. Zoom and pan to explore the chart.

This story is about two kinds of workers in America: ←Sitters—people who sit for living—and Standers→—those who stand, crouch, crawl, and lift. Over the past few generations, work in America has become far [less physical](https://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/2006/03/art3full.pdf). A lot of farming and factory work was replaced by desk jobs. In turn, work became less backbreaking—and less dangerous. >>fatalities|Workplace safety since 1970|Source: US Department of Labor|Chart showing workers are injured and killed less on the job since 1970.

But our society still needs lots of people to do physical, grueling jobs. To understand who does these jobs, I analyzed a federal survey that asked workers what they are physically required to do for their job.
The [Occupational Requirements Survey](https://www.bls.gov/ors/) talked to workers at more than 56,000 workplaces. A small portion of jobs do not have data for various physical requirements, so those were left out of this visualization.
Let’s first look at ←Sitters.

story.text: Sitters often have jobs that require a bachelor’s degree.

story.hl: A_MEAN
story.text: In turn, Sitters tend to have higher incomes.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required once per day
story.text: Sitters are more likely to have to solve problems every day.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with the ability to pause work
story.text: And Sitters get more autonomy. These are workers who say they can pause work when they need to.

story.hl: Percent of workers, with telework available
story.text: Sitters are also more likely to say they can work remotely. Only a tiny portion of Americans have this option.
Now let’s focus on Standers →.

story.hl: Percent of workers, problem solving is required less often than monthly, including never
story.text: Standers are more likely to say they never or rarely have to problem-solve for their job.

story.hl: Percent of workers, crouching is required
story.text: Standers are more likely to say they crouch at work—everyone from nurses to electricians.

story.hl: Percent of workers, climbing ladders, ropes, or scaffolds is required
story.text: Standers are also more likely to climb ladders, ropes, or scaffolds. This includes firefighters and janitors.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to wetness
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to wetness, like water, sewage, or bodily fluids.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to extreme heat
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to extreme heat from things like stoves and fires.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to outdoors
story.text: Standers are more likely to be exposed to the outdoors—something that will become more and more dangerous as our planet warms.

story.hl: Percent of workers, exposed to hazardous contaminants
story.text: And Standers are more likely to be exposed to hazardous contaminants.

story.hl: Percent of workers, without the ability to pause work
story.text: Standers often lack autonomy. These workers say they lack control over when they can take a break.

story.text:
The history of labor in America is defined by the least privileged people doing the least desirable work—sometimes by force.


America got rich selling cotton picked by enslaved Black people. America built the Transcontinental Railroad with Chinese immigrant labor, only to ban Chinese immigration a few decades later. And America feeds itself with animals killed and processed by Black and Hispanic meatpackers.

story.hl: black_pct
story.text: Black workers are more likely to be Standers. They disproportionately occupy jobs like correctional officers and cashiers.

story.hl: asian_pct
story.text: Asian workers are more likely to be Sitters, with jobs in software development and as manicurists.

story.hl: hisp_pct
story.job: Cooks, restaurant|Maids and housekeeping cleaners|Construction laborers
story.text: Hispanic workers are far more likely to be Standers, with jobs in kitchens, housekeeping, and construction.

story.hl: noncitizen_pct
story.job: Roofer|Painters, construction and maintenance|Sewing machine operators
story.text: One reason is that immigrant workers from Latin America are more likely to be Standers, working demanding—often dangerous—jobs for low pay.

story.hl: white_pct
story.job: General and operations managers|Bookkeeping, accounting, and auditing clerks
story.text: White workers are more likely to be Sitters. But they account for the majority of the workforce, so they’re also the largest group of Standers.

For most of American history, people [worked until their bodies gave out](https://www.ssa.gov/history/pdf/80chap5.pdf). In 1900, most men older than 65 still worked to be self-sufficient, including 84% of Black Americans.


>>retired|Percentage of men older than 65 who are retired|Source: The Evolution of Retirement, by Dora L. Costa|Chart showing that most men older than 65 worked in 1900. 


In 1935, President Franklin Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act, and by 1940, people who were [65 and older](https://www.ssa.gov/oact/progdata/nra.html) started receiving [monthly checks](https://www.aarp.org/retirement/social-security/info-2020/social-security-history-timeline.html). In other words, Social Security helped people to retire.

story.hl: nonwhite_pct
story.text:
But the bill [excluded](https://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/ssb/v70n4/v70n4p49.html) agricultural and domestic workers. This meant most nonwhite workers did not qualify — about 6 million people.


>>excluded|Percentage of workers excluded from Social Security, by race|Source: US Social Security Administration; US Census|Chart showing most Black workers were excluded from Social Security when the bill first passed.


This also meant the least privileged white workers were also left out — about 11.5 million people.


We still exclude people from Social Security. Since the mid-1990s, undocumented immigrants [haven’t received](https://www.everycrsreport.com/files/20161117_RL32004_1ac9e95f5f95d1df7d25727b9ed75b47fca246e4.html#_Toc515613603) Social Security benefits, even though they pay taxes to fund the system. Many will [never](https://www.wsj.com/economy/retirement-social-security-benefits-illegal-immigrants-c5a04d74_) be able to retire.

We often fetishize manual labor. 


During the pandemic, we celebrated front-line workers for keeping the world running. 


During every presidential campaign, candidates have photo ops with servers, construction workers, and farmers. They never forget to mention their teenage job as a cashier.

But then we segregate ourselves from those workers with food delivery apps, next-day shipping, and self-checkout kiosks. We don’t want to see how the sausage is made or delivered.


And then we  [oppose](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2021/04/22/most-americans-support-a-15-federal-minimum-wage/) minimum wage increases. We try to [roll back](https://publicintegrity.org/politics/system-failure/deaths-cutbacks-workplace-safety-inspections-osha/) workplace safety laws. We constantly [propose](https://www.crfb.org/blogs/what-would-trump-campaign-plans-mean-social-security) cutting Social Security benefits.


The message is clear: When it’s convenient, we’ll celebrate this work. 


Every other day, we’ll treat people who do this work as bodies for labor.
